MotionManifolds.jl

Overview

Documentation for MotionManifolds.jl, a small library to manipulate matrix Lie groups frequently encountered in robotics.

A working minimal example:

julia> skew(SA_F64[1,2,3])
3×3 SMatrix{3, 3, Float64, 9} with indices SOneTo(3)×SOneTo(3):
  0.0  -3.0   2.0
  3.0   0.0  -1.0
 -2.0   1.0   0.0

Contents:

  • MotionManifolds.jl
  • Overview
    • Library
    • Manifold manipulations
    • Computation of derivatives
    • Utils

Library

The convention is that Lie groups are denoted with upper case letters, while their respective Lie algebra are denoted with lower case letters.

Special Orthogonal 2:

MotionManifolds.SO2 — Type
	SO2
source
MotionManifolds.so2 — Type
so2 { w::Float64 }
source

Special Euclidian 2

MotionManifolds.SE2 — Type
SE2 { t::SVector{2,Float64}, rot::SO2 }

Possible constructors: SE2(x,y,th), SE2(t, rot), SE2(t, th), SE2(X::SMatrix)

source
MotionManifolds.se2 — Type
se2 {  vx::Float64, vy::Float64, w::Float64  }
source

Special Orthogonal 3

Special Orthogonal 3:

MotionManifolds.SO3 — Type
struct SO3
  u::SVector{3,Float64}
  w::Float64
  R::SMatrix{3,3,Float64,9}
end

Possible constructors: SO3(R); SO3(u,w); SO3(uw)

source
MotionManifolds.so3 — Type
struct so3
  u::SVector{3,Float64}
  w::Float64
end

$\mathfrak{so}(3)$

source
MotionManifolds.so3 — Method
so3(uw::SVector{3,Float64})

Constructor for $\mathfrak{so}(3)$

source

Special Euclidian 3

MotionManifolds.SE3 — Type
SE3 {  t::SVector{3,Float64}, rot::SO3  }

Possible constructors: SE3(t, rot),

source
MotionManifolds.se3 — Type
se3 { v::SVector{3,Float64}, w::so3 }

Possible constructors: se3(v,uw::SVector3), se3(v, uw::so3), se3(v, u, w)

source

MotionManifolds.ExpAndJr — Function
ExpAndJr(tau::SVector{3,Float64}) -> (SE2, Jr_exp)

Returns the group manifold object directly from a vector representation of a Lie algebra element. Also returns the right Jacobian, as it allows to save some computations compared to doing the 2 things separately.

source

Utils

MotionManifolds.skew — Function
skew(a::SVector{3,Float64})

Compute the 3x3 skew matrix of a 3d vector

Example

julia> skew()
2×2 SMatrix{2, 2, Float64, 4} with indices SOneTo(2)×SOneTo(2):
 0.0  -1.0
 1.0   0.0
source
skew(a::Number=1)

Compute the 2x2 skew of a number (1 by default)

source
MotionManifolds.is_skew — Function
is_skew(M)

Check if a matrix is skewed.
